ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Scientific presentation skills, knowledge about non-ribosomal protein synthesis from a mechanistic perspective.
A follow up on CHEM 419. Presented interesting concepts of chemical biology, particularly enzyme catalysis and design.
A terrific exercise in applying the knowledge of chemistry to the understanding of biological systems. I especially enjoyed the exercise in biochemical synthesis and logic.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course covered more mechanisms than chemical biology techniques. I wish the course could have provided more modern relevant topics from literature, and how to think experimentally. This was a good foundations/fundamental knowledge course, but I don't see the content on mechanisms being too valuable for my research. I liked the chemical genetics and the final lecture, where there was more applicability to experimental design and results. If the beginning material on mechanisms could be built up to relevant experiments from literature, that would be nice.

Strengths: the content and the instructor.
Weaknesses: none

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course was paced well, had an excellent instructor, and had a good workload. For students who haven't had strong organic chemistry/ chemical biology background, this course is arguably essential. Having a strong organic chemistry background and having taken a natural products synthesis course in undergraduate studies, a lot of the content presented in the first half to the first 2/3rds of the course was review of what I had seen before.
Yes, it's a great course to get exposure to chemical biology principles.
Yes, a great class in learning/applying chemistry to biologic systems.
